Liquid Tables

05 Jul 2000

How do you make a web page that looks good no matter how wide the browser window is?\nUse liquid tables, a technique that lets you "pour" your content into the page so that\nit flows to the margins, even if the window is resized.

Wait a sec, doesn't the good old HTML <p> tag allow content to flow? Yes, but \nthe problem is, you often need parts of the page to remain fixed, such as a \nnavigation bar down one side. The challenge is to have both a fixed and a flexible \nportion of the page.\nThis is where liquid tables will help you.

Let's start with some definitions:

\n
\n

ice: fixed width

\n

jello: somewhat flexible, often centered

\n

liquid: flexible width

\n

Here are a couple of good explanations of the basic differences \nbetween these three techniques:

\n
    \n

  • ice, jello, and liquid\n
    http://whatis.techtarget.com/
      WhatIs_Definition_Page/0,4152,212307,00.html

    • \n

  • Liquid Web Design: Build it right and it will work no matter what the container\n
    http://www.digital-web.com/  tutorials/tutorial_1999-10.shtml

    • \n

The problem with an "ice" design, which might use a fixed table width of, say, 600 pixels,\nis that if the browser window is narrower than 600, you get a horizontal scrollbar, and\nif the browser window is very much wider than 600, you get a lot of white space.

One type of "jello" design also uses a fixed width table,\nbut centered in the window -- this looks somewhat better\nwhen the browser window is substantially wider than the table.\nAnother type uses a table that is a certain percentage of the browser window, say 80%.\nThis allows the table to expand or contract depending on the width\nof the browser window, and it minimizes the\namount of white space at all widths. But it doesn't allow for \na fixed portion, that stays fixed -- for that, you need to use a liquid table.

The general approach to creating a liquid table is this:

\n
    \n

  1. give pixel widths to fixed columns

    2. \n

  2. give percentage widths to liquid columns

    3. \n

However, you may still run into problems. Some browsers\nwill disregard the pixel widths and try to "balance"\nthe widths of the columns. Therefore you need\nsome way to "force" the liquid columns to expand\nas much as possible.

Let's take a look at some techniques. The following resources\ngive detailed explanations for how to build liquid tables:

\n
    \n

  • Simply - Liquid Tables\n
    www.kallback.co.za/simply/float.htm

    • \n

  • Flexible Table Manners\n
    www.builder.com/Authoring/  Tagmania/102599/?tag=st.cn.sr1.dir

    • \n

  • Unpredictable Column Widths\n
    www.netmechanic.com/news/vol3/html_no2.htm

    • \n

  • Making a Wild Card Column Width\n
    www.netmechanic.com/news/vol3/html_no3.htm

    • \n

Note that one of the resources suggests that you not\nspecify a percentage width for the table. Does this work? Yup, but\nit assumes the liquid column has enough content to push the table out\nto the window margins, otherwise the fixed column tends to \nexpand beyond its specified pixel width. Remember, browsers \nregard column widths only as a recommendation, usually a minimum.\nAnd they will happily override the stated width if necessary, and make\nthe fixed column either narrower or wider.

Another approach does not use\npercentage widths for the liquid columns, but rather\nan "absurd" fixed column width such as 2000 pixels.\nThis forces the liquid column to "squeeze"\nthe fixed column, thereby keeping it to its minimum width.\nThis technique assumes a table percentage width, which most browsers\n(Opera is an exception) will honour -- specifying width=100% for the\ntable will "override" the absurdly large column width.\nThis technique probably dates back to HTML 3.2 when\npercentages were not allowed on columns -- see the W3C\nHTML 3.2 table specs.\nPercentages for columns are\nvalid in the\nHTML 4\ntable specs,\nso it now makes sense to\ngive the liquid column a cell width of 90% or 100%. But be warned that\nolder browsers may disregard these percentages if they\nwere written for HTML 3.2.

In either case you will probably need to ensure that \nthe fixed columns do not get squeezed narrower than their minimum \npixel widths, and the most reliable way seems to be to use\na transparent spacer gif.

Finally, with a truly liquid table, you will still have the problem\nof long lines of text at very wide window widths.\nOne way to deal with this\nis to use a table width of less than 100% -- say 80%.\nThis does not eliminate the problem of long lines of text,\nit just reduces it.

The bottom line on liquid tables is that you have to test your design.\nCreate a test page like this one --

\n
    \n

  • Flexible Table test\n
    www.sam-i-am.com/misc/TestSuite/tables/flexible_width.html

    • \n
\n

Test your design in several browsers. Test it at different resolutions.\nResize the window. Try to break the design. Bump your fonts up a few notches.\nAsk for a site critique on your \nfavourite web developer discusion list.

And don't forget to have fun. ;o)
